bibl.title: Letter from Sidney Coe Howard to John J. Moran, January 12, 1933

div1.p: Howard describes his play, "Yellow Jack." He mentions taking artistic license with his treatment of the volunteer soldiers' lives for the sake of the story.

div1.head: Letter from Sidney Coe Howard to John J. Moran, January 12, 1933

opener.dateline:
157 EAST 82ND STREET
NEW YORK CITY
January 12th, 1933.

div1.p:
I have left your letter unanswered because I was giving myself time
to make sure that I could finish the job, which got postponed after my visit
to Havana by an engagement in Hollywood and by some other work I had to do.
I have just finished it and it goes on the market tonight. I shall know in
a few days whether or not any manager is interested in producing it.

I have to tell you one thing. I found that I could not stick to the
actual facts as closely as I should have liked to do and at the same time make
a play in which the characters were interesting from the beginning. I had to
make up a story about the soldiers, a story which would run along with the
experiment and keep both elements going together until they finally meet at
the moment of volunteering. Now, although my story is not a very sensational
one, I naturally hesitated to represent you, Kissinger, Folk and Jernegan as
doing anything you never did and for that reason I gave the four of you new
last names. I have written a foreword to the play which describes the actual
happenings and your part in them by name and have said in conclusion that the
play insofar as the soldiers are concerned is to be taken rather as a celebration
than a representation of your heroic conduct. I don't expect any of you to
object to this change of names. It cannot be very comfortable to think of an
actor walking around a stage impersonating oneself and inevitably getting it
all wrong. I will let you know what the managers say about the play and when
if ever it is to be produced.

I still look back on my three days in Havana last winter as a very
pleasant time, though I have pangs of conscience when I remember how you let me
impose on your generosity. The world is going forward very nicely with me
considering the times. I hope that you are not having any more troubles than
you can swing and that you and your wife and those beautiful Irish nieces who
speak the wrong languages are all enjoying the best of health.
div1.closer:
Faithfully yours, Sidney Howard. Mr. John J. Moran,
Campania Sunoca de Cuba,
Avenida Menocal No. 102-A,
Havana.
